items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Torksey river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 
Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.  Standing water remains in the surrounding area of Girton. 
No further rainfall is forecast. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. 
We expect river levels to remain high with Spring tides and snow melt until Wednesday, 15/01/2025. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and please do not drive through floodwater, as bow waves may affect adjacent properties.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are stable on the lower reaches of the river Churn. However, flooding of low lying land and roads is still possible today, 14/01/25, particularly in Cerney Wick.  It is forecast to remain mostly dry today and overnight, but with the chance of light rain or showers. We expect river levels to remain steady and begin a slow fall over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 15/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are stable or dropping along the River Windrush. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible today, 14/01/25, especially in the Bourton On The Water and Newbridge areas.  It is forecast to remain mostly dry today and overnight, but with the chance of showers. We expect river levels to continue dropping slowly over the coming days. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow, 15/01/25, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are still falling steadily on the lower River Ray. However, the flooding of low lying land and roads is still possible today, 14/01/2025, especially in the Islip areas.  It is forecast to remain predominantly dry today and overnight, but with the chance of a shower. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow, 15/01/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are slowly falling but still remain high due to the previous rainfall.  We are continually monitoring the situation and the river levels.
All areas between Ringwood and Christchurch could be affected and include all tributaries. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are high but continue to fall. Flooding remains possible through today 14/01/2025.This information is correct as of 07:30 on Tuesday 14/01/2025. 

The causeway at Welney has approximately 5 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway or the Sutton Gault causeway. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 

The Environment Agency is liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road at Welney. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. 

The weather forecast is for no further rain for the next 5 days. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself at risk. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 4pm on Tuesday 14/01/2025.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels have been steadily falling over the past few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. 

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. 

Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels remain high at the Walcot River gauge following recent heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.  

No rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, Wednesday 15/01/25. We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 15/01/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels continue to fall on the Chertsey Bourne, but may remain high for the coming days. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is still possible today, 14/01/25, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. The forecast for the next few days is dry. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 15/01/25, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The Parrett, Yeo, Isle and tributary rivers rose as a result of the heavy rain two weekends ago.
Water has overtopped and and flooded the surrounding low-lying moors. Floodwaters still persist. 
The weather outlook for Tuesday and Wednesday appears dry, with no rainfall expected. This Flood Alert will remain in force until water levels start to drop below the threshold. 
We will continue to monitor any further rainfall, the river levels and the overall situation.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 15/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

River levels are rising in response to snow melt this afternoon, Tuesday 14/01/2025. Areas most at risk include land around the River Rye and its tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, and Spittle Beck, including properties of Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, drive or cycle through flood water. Take care and consider activating your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 9pm on Tuesday, 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wiske and other tributaries of the River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck

items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding as melting snow pushes river levels up.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations  around the The River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck.
We expect snow melt to continue to melt during Tuesday and Wednesday, river levels may remain high because of this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 8:30 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message:
Flooding is still possible as the river near Beggearn Huish in West Somerset remains above the flood alert threshold of 0.35m following heavy rainfall two weekends ago. However, water levels look stable and continue to slowly fall. 
Tuesday's forecast predicts dry weather. While the Flood Alert may remain in place through till Wednesday, we are closely monitoring the weather forecast, river levels, and overall conditions. If the dry forecast holds, the alert could be lifted soon.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 15/01/2025, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.62 mAOD at 14:45 on 14/01/25.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 135 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding as melting snow pushes river levels up.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations  around the The River Swale and tributaries from Catterick Bridge to the confluence with the River Ure.
We expect snow melt to continue to melt during Tuesday and Wednesday, river levels may remain high because of this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 8:30 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has been removed as levels on the River Rede are falling.

No further flooding to fields and roads is expected.

We will continue to monitor river levels.

Please continue to take care along riverside roads and footpaths. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

River levels are rising at the Leek river gauge as a result of snowmelt and saturated ground. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected throughout this afternoon and overnight into tomorrow morning, Wednesday 15/01/25. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   
No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to rise until later this evening and remain high into tomorrow morning, Wednesday 15/01/25.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 14/01/25, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of further flooding at Currymoor Reservoir caused by the River Tone two weekends ago. However, standing water may still remain. 
The weather outlook for the rest of the week looks largely dry, with no further rainfall expected. 
Pumping operations continue at Currymoor with all available pumps. Water levels are gradually receding and are down to around 25% full. 
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through any standing water.

Following yesterday's rainfall and recent snow melt, river levels in the area are higher than normal but are expected to start falling in the next hour.  Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the day and no further flooding is expected.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Esk and Irthing and other watercourses, including low lying areas around Longtown and Brampton.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding as melting snow pushes river levels up.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Skell, River Ure, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low-lying land including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton.
We expect snow to continue to melt during Tuesday and Wednesday, river levels may remain high because of this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 7:30 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Boroughbridge Camping and Caravanning Site
items.message:
Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding this morning as melting snow pushes river levels up.
Flooding is expected from 8:45 AM on 14/01/2025.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ure, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Boroughbridge Camping and Caravanning Site.
We expect snow to continue to melt during Tuesday and Wednesday, river levels may remain high because of this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 3:45 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Following yesterday's rainfall and recent snow melt, river and lake levels in the area are slowly rising and will continue to do so throughout the morning. Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the afternoon and levels will then begin to fall.  We are not expecting to issue any flood warnings.

Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 15/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels in the middle river Aire catchment have slowly risen, primarily due to thawing snow. Flooding may occur on low-lying park/farmland next to the river and its tributaries. At this stage we do not expect properties to flood from the River Aire. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through floodwater. 

No significant rain is expected over the coming days. We do not currently expect to issue any flood warnings but continue to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 18:30 on Tuesday 14th January 2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding as melting snow pushes river levels up.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations  around the River Nidd and its tributaries including Thornton Beck, Newton Beck, Oak Beck, Cow Dyke Beck, Bilton Beck, Frogmire Dike and Syke Dike. 
We expect snow melt to continue to melt during Tuesday and Wednesday, river levels may remain high because of this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 8:30 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high and are expected to respond to recent rainfall, levels are likely to respond from the 8th of January onwards. Levels are very reactive to further rainfall. 

Flooding of roads and fields is possible. Where groundwater is near the surface, intense rainfall will lead to surface water flooding.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

This message will be updated by 3 PM on 14/1/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next week.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall, Low-lying land, roads and basements may be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 21/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently stable at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn Valley. However, groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the coming weeks if levels begin rising again.

We expect levels to remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall.  Low-lying land, roads and basements could be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message in a week, 21/01/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are high and rising. In the last week, over half a month’s rain (69mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton. During this time, the level at Preston Candover has risen by 30cm. In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, a small number of properties are expected to be experiencing cellar flooding. Septic tanks in Old Alresford will be struggling to operate effectively. Further rainfall is forecast on Wednesday 08/01/2025 and Friday 10/01/2025, with up to 15mm expected on each day. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising slowly for around 2 weeks in response to this rain. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Tuesday 14/01/2025.

Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill, close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high effective rainfall during the Autumn and early Winter, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. This rise is from levels which were already high from the previous Winter. Levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the coming months in response to the high Autumn and early Winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 15th January 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are currently rising very slowly at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton following rainfall over recent weeks.

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. We expect levels to continue rising slowly over the coming week and levels will remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding.

Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week, 21/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding as melting snow pushes river levels up.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations  around the Upper River Nidd and its tributaries including How Stean Beck, Blayshaw Gill, Ramsgill Beck, Lul Beck, Foster Beck, Fosse Gill, Fell Beck and Darley Beck.
We expect snow to continue to melt during Tuesday and Wednesday, river levels may remain high because of this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 8:30 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding as melting snow pushes river levels up.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations around the River Crimple and River Nidd, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Crimple and its tributaries including Horn Beck, Clark Beck, Hookstone Beck, Rud Beck, Toad Hole Beck and Park Beck.
We expect snow melt to continue during Tuesday and Wednesday, river levels may remain high because of this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:30 PM on 14/01/2025, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston
items.message: River levels in the Minor Watercourses from Heighington to Dunston remain high as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the rivers is expected to continue. No further rain is forecast for the next few days, however we expect the rivers to remain high and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the rivers. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine on 15/01/25, or before if the situation changes.

In Hursley, groundwater levels have fallen by 7cm since Monday 06/01/2025 following a week of mostly dry weather. Groundwater levels in the village peaked earlier than expected and below the level we would expect cellar flooding impacts to occur. During this week, the weather is expected to remain fairly dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue to slowly fall. We continue to monitor the groundwater levels and weather forecast. If further heavy and persistent rainfall affects the area during the winter, then groundwater flooding impacts are a possibility. We will issue further advice if we think groundwater levels will affect property.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in the villages surrounding Andover are high and slowly rising. In the last week, the level at Clanville has risen by 60cm. In Appleshaw, a small number of properties are expected to begin experiencing cellar flooding from today (13/01/2025). In Hatherden, a small number of cellars could be affected from Wednesday (15/01/2025). Groundwater is affecting the sewerage network at Penton Mewsey and the main road into Penton Grafton is flooded. Groundwater will emerge in many of the ditches and roads in most villages. During this week, the weather is expected to remain mostly dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue rising for another week in response to the rain recorded in early January. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove any valuables from cellars. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Monday 20/01/2025.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, standing water remains around the village of Girton with limited access.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: In Deane and Ashe, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise slowly. In the last 7 days, the level has risen by 34cm. In the last 3 months, 265mm of rain has been recorded at Overton. This is more than the long-term average rainfall expected for this period. The River Test will be flowing in Deane and Ashe. Rising groundwater will also begin to affect the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. During this week, the weather will remain fairly dry, but groundwater will continue to rise for most of January, in response to the rainfall recorded at the beginning of the month. We continue to monitor the forecast. In Deane, we would like residents to prepare for cellar flooding impacts, which are possible by the end of January. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. We will update this Flood Alert by 17:00 on Monday 20/01/2025.
